conclusion: Analyze the motion of the charged small ball under the influence of gravity and the electric field.
The small ball falls vertically between two uncharged vertical parallel metal plates.
The force due to gravity is G = mg, where m is the mass of the ball and g is the acceleration due to gravity.
The initial velocity of the ball is v_0 (downward).
When a voltage U is applied between the two plates, an electric field E is created, where E = U/d.
The force on the charged ball due to the electric field is F = qE = qU/d, where q is the charge on the ball.
The angle of the trajectory is 45°, which means the horizontal and vertical components of the velocity are equal in magnitude.
Let the horizontal component of the velocity be v_x and the vertical component be v_y. Since the angle is 45°, we have v_x = v_y.
The vertical component of the velocity remains v_y = v_0 - gt (where t is the time of flight).
The horizontal component of the velocity is v_x = qU/md * t.
Since v_x = v_y, we have v_0 - gt = qU/md * t.
From the equation v_0 - gt = qU/md * t, solve for q: q = (v_0 md - mgdt) / Ut.
The time to reach the point of turning is t = v_0/g (from the vertical motion).
Substitute t = v_0/g into the horizontal component equation: qU v_0/mgd = v_0 - v_0.
The charge amount of the small ball is q = mgd/U.
